Group.name: Main
Group.Text: The changed language settings will take effect the next time you restart the game. Do you want to restart the game now?
Do you want to quit the game?

Group.name: About
Group.Text:
Ballance Rebuild is an open-source Unity remake of the Ball Ball game, produced by IMengyu.

You can play this remastered version, and you can also create custom modules or maps based on this remastered version to share with other players.

The source code of the project is stored in https://github.com/imengyu/Ballance 。

If you encounter bugs or have great ideas, please feel free to visit the project homepage https://github.com/imengyu/Ballance Submit your issue and let's discuss it together.

If you want to develop your own mod and level for Ballance, welcome to https://github.com/imengyu/Ballance/wiki Learn about related tutorials!

Welcome to discuss the game at Ballance Discord.

Group.name: Start
Group.Text:
You can load a standard old Ballance original level (NMO file). Most levels can be successfully loaded and played, but there are a few limitations: 
Cannot load levels with Virtools scripts. 
Does not support Virtools point, line mesh. 
Materials do not support Virtools special effects and will use default materials instead. 
Does not support setting level sky box, level score, no background music.

Group.name: TutorialText
Group.Text: Game Tutorial:\nYou may halt or quit the game any time using the "ESC" key.\nYou may continue the game tutorial with the "RETURN" key or quit the tutorial by pressing "Q".
View Rotation: \nKeep the left "SHIFT" key pressed and use the "LEFT" or "RIGHT" ARROW key to rotate the view in 90 steps.\nContinue with "RETURN" ...

Overview:
Hold down the "SPACEBAR" to raise the viewpoint.

Continue with "RETURN" ...

Navigation:
Turn the view until the track with the two towers is in front of you.
Use the "ARROW" keys (without "SHIFT") to move the ball forward, backward, left and right.
Follow the path!

Life Extra:
If you fall off the track, you lose one life. Your remaining lifes are displayed at the right bottom of the screen. You receive an additional life by picking up a "Life Extra".

Continue with "RETURN" ...

Transformer:
With the use of "transformers" you can change the material of the ball. The material of the transformer field indicates the type of transformer. 
This is a stone transformer.

Continue with "RETURN" ...

This slope is too steep for a stoneball!
Look for a wood transformer and try again. 
Hint: Turn the view (SHIFT + RIGHT/LEFT), to get a better orientation. Rolling backwards can be dangerous!
Continue with "RETURN" ...

Point Extra:
The display on the left shows your actual time-points, which are constantly decreasing during the game. You increase your score by picking up a Point Extra.

Continue with "RETURN" ...

Checkpoints:
This is the first checkpoint you have to pass.
In case you loose a life during the game, you can continue the game from the last checkpoint.

Continue with "RETURN" ...

Some hints at the end:
In case you get stuck at some point or need some technical help, please take a look at the "Ballance HTML Help", which is accessible via the Windows Start Menu (not during the game!).

Quit the tutorial with "RETURN" ...

Group.name: LevelLoaderErrorUI
Group.Text: Don't worry, it's not your fault, just try another level. If it's a level created by another player, try giving them feedback. \nLevel Developer: You can enter the developer mode and press F12 to enter the console to see more error messages.

Group.name: package
Group.Text: Ballance base system package, including all base ball and base moduls
Ballance base system package, including all the base ball and the base moduls, is the base of all the MOD dependence, can not be uninstalled.

Group.name: toolbar
Group.Text: Toggle tool handle position.\nPovit: The tool handle is placed at actived object's poivt point.\nCenter: The tool handle is placed at center of selection.
Toggle tool handle Rotation.\nGlobal: Tool handles are in global rotation.\nLocal: Tool handles are in local rotation.

Group.name: import
Group.Text: You can import custom 3D models made by other software into the current level, you can use 3dsMax or Blender to make custom models, custom models can achieve more complex effects. \n\nImport tips: Support FBX,OBJ and other formats of 3D files, it is recommended that you export a single model, import successful resources will appear in the assets library, you can drag and drop into the level at any time.
For some materials in your model, if they have the same name as the in-game material, they are automatically replaced with the in-game higher-definition built-in material
Set the scale of the model, less than 1 is reduced, equal to 1 is maintained the original scale, greater than 1 is enlarged
You need to define what function the model is used for, such as is it a road or a rail? Or no interactive decorative model?
A wooden ball is displayed in the scene for reference to whether the proportions are correct
It may be that the model you loaded is invalid or the file cannot be read. Error: {0}
The model is too small, maybe the scale is not correct
The model is too large, maybe the scale is not correct
Set the name for your new model to displayed in the asset library
This is the custom model that you imported
Import failed, possibly the model is not supported, error message: {0}
Import success! Assets can be found in the "My Assets" category

Group.name: help
Group.Text: The test mode is a simulation environment that allows you to test whether your level is playable, in the here you can reset the ball at any time, reset the modul at any time, and the ball can fly up and down. \n\nTip: Before entering the test mode, select the checkpoint, you can start playing from the checkpoint!
Tip: Select custom to customize the sky picture

Welcome to the level Editor! 

The Level Editor is a free testing ground where you can create your own unique levels and mazes to play with. You can also share your own levels with other players. 
When you finish editing the level, you can click "Play" to enter the test ground mode, and test whether the level is playable at any time.

<size=+1>Moving and rotating camera</size>

Hold down the right mouse button <sprite=6> then drag the mouse to rotate view.
Hold down the middle mouse button <sprite=7> Then drag the mouse to pan the view.
Hold down the right mouse button <sprite=6> Then use <sprite=1> key can also rotate view, press <sprite=2> key can move down the view, press <sprite=3> key can move up the view.

<size=+1>Select, add, and delete objects</size>

Use the left mouse button <sprite=5> click to select the object in the level.
Select the object you want to add in the Asset library, then drag and drop it into the level to add it. 
Click the Delete button on the toolbar to delete the selected object.

As you can see, below is the asset library of the level, the game has a lot of assets built into the level, including roads, rails, moduls, decorations, you can select them, drag them into the scene to add.

Editable component\nThe game has built-in editable components, such as deformable roads and rails, you can find assets with "editable" marks in the asset library to add, you can choose a variety of deformation type, such as straight lines, curves, spirals, etc.
You can also import your own 3D models into the scene using other software, such as Blender, 3DSMax, etc., to make your own roads, rail, etc., supporting 3D files in FBX, OBJ, etc.
<size=+1>Basic parts</size>\n\nA complete level consists of the following components, and you need to add these components if your level is to be playable. Their functions are described below.

<size=+1>Start point</size>

The player starts the game from here, and only one of these components can exist in the level. When you create a new level, the system automatically creates it for you. 
The birth point can be found in the Asset library "Moduls" > "Basic".

<size=+1>Check point</size>

Checkpoints are used to save the player's progress, and when the player fails to fall, he can continue playing from the nearest checkpoint.
Checkpoint properties can be set in which sector it is, you need to set the sector sequence number according to your own level route.
Can be found in the Asset library "Moduls" > "Basic".

<size=+1>Sector</size>

Sector are areas of the level that are divided by checkpoints, and you can add several checkpoints to divide your level into sectors so that players can continue playing from the nearest checkpoint if they fail.

Each modul needs to set the sector in which it is activated in the property Settings, so that when the user enters the section, the modul will be activated, and after the user falls to reset, the modul with the section set can also reset the initial state.

<size=+1>End ship</size>

The end ship is the end of the level, and the player pass the level after boarding the ship.
When you create a new level, the system automatically creates it for you.
Can be found in the Asset library "Moduls" > "Basic".

<size=+1>Fall test cube</size>

The Fall test cube is used to detect when a player falls from the road, and when the player's ball hit this area, it is considered a failure.
Can be found in the Asset library "Moduls" > "Basic".

<size=+1>Moduls</size>

Modul is a special interactive part of the game, it adds a lot of fun to the game, multiple moduls combined with each other, can also form a more interesting maze, play your imagination to place the modul. If you want to make your own moduls that are not in the game, you need to develop mods, which can be specific to the game Wiki.
Game internal moduls can be found in the Asset library "Moduls".

When your level is finished and playable, you can share it to the Steam Workshop for other players to play, click the "Publish" button to display the share window, fill in the level introduction information, and then share it.
